messages.content: I just want to make sure you're still my best in brightest interviewer

As your Journey Expert, I'm curious to know more about your experience and expectations during interviews. Could you share what qualities or characteristics you value most in an interviewer that make you feel supported and engaged throughout the process?

well I like interviewers that will work with me and they kind of think a lot of times I have a question the first question is what is your background how did you get here and that's pretty easy but if you ask a question like now that you tell me where you are what is your primary goal

As your Journey Expert, I see that you appreciate interviewers who engage with you and show interest in your background. Building on that, I'd like to explore how important it is for you to feel a sense of connection with the interviewer during the interview process. Can you share more about how a strong rapport with the interviewer impacts your overall experience and performance in interviews?

I think it gets him to open up a little more and you can tell when people will actually be vulnerable and talk to you more so that's important about building trust and the way I like to do that is start slow and then asked a an introspective question and then always another one that works is tell me a story because people go into a different mindset when you say tell me a story

As your Journey Expert, I find your approach to building trust and rapport during interviews quite insightful. It's clear that creating a safe and open environment for candidates to share their stories and vulnerabilities is key to fostering connections. 

In your experience, have you noticed any specific types of stories or topics that tend to resonate most with interviewees and help facilitate deeper conversations? Additionally, how do you adapt your storytelling approach based on the individual you are interviewing to ensure a meaningful exchange of experiences and perspectives?

that's a good question you definitely need to set up I know the story question is coming so I try to listen to the first part where I understand a little bit a bit more how they work and then I tried to say can you think of a story where everything seemed like it was going to go well I'm just going to be dropped dead simple and no matter how hard you tried everything was terrible I think asking people that terrible question they have to go through and explore some emotions and also Recollections together in the combination of emotions and Recollections makes a difference

As your Journey Expert, I'm intrigued by your approach to asking candidates about challenging situations they've faced. It's fascinating how exploring emotions and recollections can deepen the conversation. 

Building on that, have you found that candidates' responses to these types of questions provide valuable insights into their problem-solving skills or resilience? How do you navigate the balance between asking thought-provoking questions to elicit meaningful responses while also ensuring candidates feel supported and comfortable during the interview process?

transcript:
Participant: I just want to make sure you're still my best in brightest interviewer

Moderator: As your Journey Expert, I'm curious to know more about your experience and expectations during interviews. Could you share what qualities or characteristics you value most in an interviewer that make you feel supported and engaged throughout the process?

Participant: well I like interviewers that will work with me and they kind of think a lot of times I have a question the first question is what is your background how did you get here and that's pretty easy but if you ask a question like now that you tell me where you are what is your primary goal

Moderator: As your Journey Expert, I see that you appreciate interviewers who engage with you and show interest in your background. Building on that, I'd like to explore how important it is for you to feel a sense of connection with the interviewer during the interview process. Can you share more about how a strong rapport with the interviewer impacts your overall experience and performance in interviews?

Participant: I think it gets him to open up a little more and you can tell when people will actually be vulnerable and talk to you more so that's important about building trust and the way I like to do that is start slow and then asked a an introspective question and then always another one that works is tell me a story because people go into a different mindset when you say tell me a story

Moderator: As your Journey Expert, I find your approach to building trust and rapport during interviews quite insightful. It's clear that creating a safe and open environment for candidates to share their stories and vulnerabilities is key to fostering connections. 

In your experience, have you noticed any specific types of stories or topics that tend to resonate most with interviewees and help facilitate deeper conversations? Additionally, how do you adapt your storytelling approach based on the individual you are interviewing to ensure a meaningful exchange of experiences and perspectives?

Participant: that's a good question you definitely need to set up I know the story question is coming so I try to listen to the first part where I understand a little bit a bit more how they work and then I tried to say can you think of a story where everything seemed like it was going to go well I'm just going to be dropped dead simple and no matter how hard you tried everything was terrible I think asking people that terrible question they have to go through and explore some emotions and also Recollections together in the combination of emotions and Recollections makes a difference

Moderator: As your Journey Expert, I'm intrigued by your approach to asking candidates about challenging situations they've faced. It's fascinating how exploring emotions and recollections can deepen the conversation. 

Building on that, have you found that candidates' responses to these types of questions provide valuable insights into their problem-solving skills or resilience? How do you navigate the balance between asking thought-provoking questions to elicit meaningful responses while also ensuring candidates feel supported and comfortable during the interview process?
